metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City I v. Manilal

facts.text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as an individual in respect of his income for the assessment year 1954-55.
The taxing authorities included in the assessee's total income two sums: Rs. 410/- and Rs. 14,170/-, stated to have accrued in the relevant account year.
On January 12, 1953, the assessee created a trust in respect of a sum of Rs. 25,000/-, trustees being Central Bank Executor Trustee Co., the assessee himself, his wife and brother.

Scheme of the 1953 trust-deed: Rs. 25,000/- set apart, interest accumulated and added to corpus; minor daughter Chandrika to receive income from enlarged corpus when she attains age of 18 on February 1, 1959, during her lifetime.
Income derived from the 1953 trust fund amounted to Rs. 410/- in the relevant account year, included in assessee's total income under s. 16(3)(b) and/or s. 16(3)(a)(iv).

On December 1, 1941, assessee's father created a trust in respect of some shares and cash sum of Rs. 30,000/- for benefit of his four sons including the assessee; trustees: Central Bank Executor and Trustee Co. Ltd., assessee and one other person.

Under 1941 trust deed, trustees to hold funds upon trust to pay net interest and income to assessee for maintenance of himself and his wife and for maintenance, education and benefit of all his children till his death.
Rs. 14,170/- accrued as income in hands of assessee in relevant account year from 1941 trust funds; taxing authorities and Tribunal viewed assessee as sole beneficiary, not accountable to anyone.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, on appeal by assessee, did not accept assessee's contentions and upheld inclusion of both sums.
Tribunal stated case to Bombay High Court under s. 66(1) on two questions of law.
Bombay High Court answered both questions in favour of assessee by judgment dated September 25, 1958, and granted certificate under s. 66A(2).
In relevant account year, Chandrika was still a minor, had no right to trust income or beneficial interest; income accumulated and added to corpus.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 410/- is properly includible in the assessee's total income either in accordance with the provisions of section 16(3)(b) and/or section 16(3)(a)(iv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?
Whether the sum of Rs. 14,170/- is properly includible in the total income of the assessee as the sole beneficiary thereof under the trust settlement made on 1-12-1941 by Dhanji Devsi?

petitioner_arguments.text: Rs. 410/- includible under s.16(3)(b) as income of trustees arising from assets transferred by assessee otherwise than for adequate consideration for benefit of his minor child Chandrika; conditions of cl.(b) fulfilled: income in hands of trustees, from transferred assets, for minor child's benefit.
Rs. 14,170/- includible in assessee's total income as he is sole beneficiary under 1941 trust, received for his own benefit, not accountable to anyone.
Cl. 7 of 1941 trust merely expresses motive of gift, not imposing trust; assessee holds beneficial interest, no second trust possible under s.8 Indian Trusts Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Rs. 410/- not includible as Chandrika had no right to income or beneficial interest in relevant year; neither s.16(3)(a)(iv) nor s.16(3)(b) applies.

Rs. 14,170/- not includible as sole beneficiary; beneficiaries are assessee, wife and children; assessee received in trust, shares indeterminate; Department may assess under first proviso to s.41(1) at maximum rate.

court_reasoning.text: During Chandrika's minority, income accumulated and added to corpus; she had no right to income or benefit in relevant year; s.16(3)(b) requires minor child to derive some benefit in year of account (receive, accrue, or beneficial interest); no such benefit, so not includible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of s.16 requires benefit to minor in relevant year; tax on yearly basis per s.4.

court_reasoning.text: Cls.(a) and (b) of s.16(3) read together; cl.(b) covers trusts to prevent evasion of cl.(a), but still requires benefit to minor in year of account; illustrations: post-majority, intermediate beneficiaries, partial income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No benefit to minor = no inclusion, consistent with anti-avoidance purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.7 of 1941 trust creates binding trust: trustees pay income to assessee on trust for maintenance of himself, wife, children; not mere wish; assessee trustee, not sole beneficiary; shares indeterminate, assessable under s.41(1) proviso.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two trusts created by single deed; enforceable obligation from language.

court_reasoning.text: s.64(1)(v) IT Act 1961 clarifies 'immediate or deferred benefit' but not declaratory of 1922 Act; English cases on differently worded provisions not applicable.

holdings.text: Rs. 410/- not includible in assessee's total income under s.16(3)(b) as no benefit accrued to minor daughter in relevant year.
Rs. 14,170/- not includible as income of assessee as sole beneficiary; assessee holds as trustee for self, wife, children under s.41.

precedents_cited.relevance: English decision on s.25 Income Tax Act 1918; differently worded, not helpful.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mauray v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: English decision on s.20(1)(c) Finance Act 1922; differently worded, not helpful.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re. Booth, Booth v. Booth
precedents_cited.relevance: Income subject to trust for maintenance and education of children.
Similar view on trust for maintenance.
Similar view on trust for maintenance.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing assessment, inclusion of trust income, reference to High Court; s.16(3)(b) requires benefit to minor in relevant year; s.41 for trustee assessment.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Corresponds to s.16 of 1922 Act; clarifies deferred benefits but not retrospective.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trusts Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Subject matter of trust must be transferable property, not merely beneficial interest under subsisting trust; distinguished as two trusts created.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Bombay High Court's answers to both questions in favour of assessee; Rs. 410/- not includible under s.16(3)(b) due to no benefit to minor in relevant year; Rs. 14,170/- not includible as assessee's individual income as he is trustee under s.41.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal dismissed; inclusions set aside as per High Court.

key_quotes.text: "the scheme of the section requires that an assessee can only be taxed on the income from a trust fund for the benefit of his minor child, provided that in the year of account the minor child derives some benefit under the trust deed"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The expression 'for the maintenance of himself and his wife and for the maintenance, education and benefit of all his children' is not indicative of a mere desire or hope. It imposes a binding and obligatory trust."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holding on 1941 trust creating enforceable obligation

key_quotes.text: "Section 4, the charging section, of the Income-tax Act makes it clear that what is taxed is the total income of the relevant account year"
key_quotes.speaker: court
